title: What Meryl Streep wore to the Oscars after Chanel dress drama
text:
What Meryl Streep wore to the Oscars following dress drama with Chanel designer Karl Lagerfeld What Meryl Streep wore to the Oscars after Chanel dress drama Meryl Streep wears Elie Saab dress to Oscars after Chanel dress drama. (Chris Pizzello/Chris Pizzello/Invision/AP) NEW YORK DAILY NEWS  42 PM 
Meryl Streep made a fashion statement at the Oscars despite dress drama with Chanel designer Karl Lagerfeld. 
The 67-year-old actress, who was reportedly slated to wear Chanel to the Academy Awards, showed up in an off-the-shoulder deep blue Elie Saab number. 
Last week, Lagerfeld accused the actress of canceling a dress he was working on for her, claiming that another designer was willing to pay her to wear one of their dresses -- and even called her cheap. 
“A genius actress, but cheapness also, no?” he told Women’s Wear Daily. Oscars 2017: Winners, losers and top show moments 
Since then, Lagerfeld and Chanel apologized in a statement claiming he “misunderstood” the reason Streep chose another designer. 
Streep said the dispute was taking away from her record-breaking 20th Oscar nomination. She fired back on the eve of the award show Saturday. 
“I do not take this lightly, and Mr. Lagerfeld’s generic ‘statement’ of regret for this ‘controversy’ was not an apology. He lied, they printed the lie, and I am still waiting,” she said in a statement to People. Last week, Lagerfeld accused the actress of canceling a dress he was working on for her, claiming that another designer was willing to pay her to wear one of their dresses. (Thibault Camus/ASSOCIATED PRESS) 
Streep, who is nominated for best Actress for her role in “Florence Foster Jenkins,” stunned in the satin gown. 
During the award show, host Jimmy Kimmel joked in his opening monologue that Streep -- an outspoken critic of President Trump -- was wearing a designer by his daughter, Ivanka. 
“Nice dress...is that an Ivanka?” he quipped. 
It was a clear jab at the President, who called her “one of the most overrated actresses in Hollywood,” after she used her Golden Globes acceptance speech to take aim at the controversial travel ban. Join the Conversation:
